title: New Homes Have Been Built on an English Estate That Dates Back to the 18th Century
text:
A collection of new homes in and around a converted stately home in the historic town of Bath, England, are set to be completed later this autumn, with prices extending up to £2.4 million (US$3 million).



The development comprises a total of 54 residences, including new-build homes on the estate, plus apartments within the 18th-century converted mansion known as Hope House.



More: English Soccer Star John Terry Buys £4.35 Million Country Manor

The Grade-II listed Georgian manor was originally the home of Charles Hamilton, who had the home built around 1781. Hamilton was England’s first commercial sparkling wine vintner, according to a news release from developers Acorn Property Group and Galliard Homes.



After Hamilton’s ownership, Hope House went on to be owned by a series of aristocratic families before becoming home to Bath High School in 1926. Students at the school, which shuttered in 1998, have included celebrity cook and TV presenter Mary Berry, according to the release.



The estate continued to serve as a school until 2013, and now, after a two-year restoration and construction project, the estate is once again a residential address.



All seven apartments within the mansion have double reception rooms and master bedroom suites with walk-in dressing rooms and master bathrooms. Other features include generous ceiling heights and original doors.

Arranged around the historic Hope House are the newly built homes, which include three- and four-bedroom townhouses and one-, two- and three-bedroom apartments, the release said.

Built from honey-colored Bath Stone—a local limestone—and with sash windows and handcrafted metalwork, the new-build homes are designed to pay homage to the mansion.



“It has been a key concern for all involved to preserve the history of Hope House yet create a new future as an exclusive residential address,” David Galman, sales director at Galliard Homes, said in the release.



Of the development’s homes, 14 are currently on the market, 22 have yet to be listed and the rest have sold or are reserved, according to Acorn Property Group’s website.
